sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: The character of the servant belonging to Cromwell in Mitford's play, Charles I. No proper name given. Original role created by Mr. Kerridge.
Character of Sforza in Foscari. See also the character's historical counterpart: General Sforza.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who serves Prospero under magical duress.
Alberti is a character in Rienzi; Captain of the Guard. Played by Mr. Thompson as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.

Possibly a deleted character in Mitford's Charles I. Coles identifies the undated fragment in which Alice appears as having been written in July or August, 1823, although in her letter to Talfourd dated 9 November 1823, Mitford indicates that she will delete the scene. The character does not appear in the final version of the play.
Character from Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison who is rescued by Sir Charles from other suitors, and later marries him, becoming Lady Grandison.
Bertone, nicknamed Bert, is the character of a servant to Count D'Alba in Julian. Played by Mr. Comer as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Lord Cafarello is a character in Rienzi; one of the members of the Colonna faction. Played by Mr. Lee as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who chafes against his magically-enforced servitude to Prospero.
A character from Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison, who refuses to marry Sir Charles.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who is shipwrecked on Prospero's Island, and falls in love with Miranda. No surname given.
Character who becomes Robinson Crusoe's friend and companion in Daniel Defoe's The Adventures of Robinson Crusoe.
Titular character in Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels.
Character in Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison. She is the ward of Sir Charles Grandison.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest. She is the daughter of Prospero and is in love with Ferdinand.
Hero of Homer's The Odyssey, whose twenty-year journey to return home from the Trojan War is chronicled.
Main character from Shakespeare's The Tempest who, upon being shipwrecked on an island with his daughter, Miranda, has learned sorcery and magic.
Character in Glenfergus by Mudie.
Mischievous fairy or sprite from folklore. In Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, he causes romantic havoc for the other characters, both human and fairy.
Titular character of Daniel Defoe's famous novel about a man shipwrecked near Trinidad.
A character in Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison.
A character Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison.
Character from George Farquhar's play The Recruiting Officer. Forename not given.
Paolo is the character of Julian's servant in Julian. Surname not given. Played by Mr. Ley as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character of a jester who serves the King in Gaston de Blondeville.
Character of Count Pisani in Foscari.
The character of an Officer in the Parliamentary Army in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Addison. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Pride.

Classical god of sexual desire and erotic love, known as Eros in ancient Greece and Cupid in ancient Rome. In Roman mythology, son of the Roman goddess of love, Venus, and the messenger god, Mercury. Cupid is represented in art and myth as a handsome youth bearing a bow with arrows that he shoots into those whom he wishes to cause to fall in or out of love.

org.note: A circle of female writers and intellectuals formed around the salons hosted by Elizabeth Montagu, Frances Boscawen, and Elizabeth Vesey between 1755 and 1795. The group came to include such writers as Hannah More, Hester Chapone, Sarah Fielding, and others, emphasizing education, enlightened conversation, improvement, and exchange. While the network was thought of as female, the Bluestocking Circle did include some of the leading male figures of the day, particularly Samuel Richardson. Source: ODNB

person.note: Poet, prose writer, author of children's books, and sometime member of the Bluestocking Circle.
Author of the seminal gothic novel, Vathek, art collector, and Member of Parliament. He was the Member for Wells from 1784-1790, and later for Hindon from 1790-1795 and again from 1806-1820.
Author and member of the Bluestocking Circle.
Correspondent of Samuel Richardson, companion and friend of Sarah and Henry Fielding, accompanying the latter on his voyage to Lisbon. Source: ODNB.
Playwright, author of numerous plays, including The Recruiting Officer and The Beaux' Stratagem. Source: ODNB.

Author of novels for adults and children, including The Adventures of David Simple, and The Governess; or Little Female Academy. She was the sister of Henry Fielding, a correspondent of Samuel Richardson, and a collaborator of the sister of Margaret Collier, Jane, with whom she wrote The Cry. Source: ODNB.

person.persName: George II of Great Britain and Ireland and Elector of Hanover

persName.roleName: King of Great Britain and Ireland fromJune 22, 1727 to October 25, 1760
Prince Elector of the Holy Roman Empire
Marquess and First Duke of Cambridge, third creation, Earl of Milford Haven, Viscount Northallerton, and Baron of Tewkesbury from November 1706-June 22, 1727
Prince of Wales and Earl of Chester fromSeptember 9, 1714-June 22, 1727

person.note: King of England and Ireland, second in the Hanoverian line, and last English monarch born outside of England. His reign was marked by great polical partisanship, and ultimately the consolidation of the Hanoverian succession. The final Jacobite uprising in 1745, the Seven Years' War, the expansion of British reach into North America and elsewhere were some of the highlights of his reign. Sources: ODNB.

Poet and artist, an intimate of Samuel Richardson, who admired her literary skills, and of Hester Chapone and other Bluestockings. Her portrait is included in the picture of Richardson reading Sir Charles Grandison. Source: ODNB.
Dutch Golden Age landscape painter, a student of .

First Marquess of Exeter, and later tenth Earl of Exeter, which he succeeded to upon the death of his uncle. His secret, bigamous marriage to the farmer's daughter, Sarah Hoggins, became a popular subject for poetry and art in the nineteenth century.

Known as the Cottage Countess, Sarah Hoggins was a farmer's daughter who married Henry Cecil, who was, unbeknownst to her, the already-married heir to the Earldom of Exeter. The couple's portrait was painted by Thomas Lawrence, and the story became fodder for many nineteenth-century writers and artists, including Tennyson and John Everett Millais. Their son, who inherited the father's title, later became a patron of the poet John Clare, something Mitford mentions in her chapter on Clare in Recollections of a Literary Life.

Correspondent of Gilbert White in his Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne, Pennant was a naturalist and author whose many works included Arctic Zoology, A Tour in Scotland 1769 and A Synopsis of Quadrupeds. His travels writings influenced Samuel Johnson, and he corresponded extensively with Joseph Banks. Source: ODNB.
Dutch Golden Age landscape painter, the father of Jacob van Ruysdael, and the uncle of Jacob van Ruisdael.
Dutch Golden Age landscape painter, nephew of Salomon van Ruysdael, and cousin of Jacob van Ruysdael.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Foscari at Covent Garden Theatre in 1828. Active in London theaters in the 1820s and early 1830s. Forename unknown.More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Mitford's protege in the 1830s, mentioned in her letters. She also addressed a poem to him: On Mr. Cathcart's performance of Cromwell in the tragedy of Charles I. Macready mentions this about Cathcart's performance in Charles I: The play is wretchedly constructed, with some powerful scenes, many passages of power and considerable effect in the sketch of Cromwell's character, which, deserving first-rate support, was consigned to the murderous Mr. Cathcart--a very poor pretender indeed. Source: The Diaries of William Charles Macready, 1833-1851, volume one.Entry for July 12, 1834, page 165. Forename unknown. More research needed.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Active 1830s. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Debuted in 1816 in Bertram at Drury Lane; she also performed at Covent Garden. She married Alfred Bunn, stage manager at Drury Lane, who succeeded the Kembles and later performed under her married name as Mrs. Bunn.
Child actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays, Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823 and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. In 1833, he opened the Victoria Theatre, formerly known as the Coburg, with Daniel Egerton. He also served as manager at the Haymarket Theatre and later moved to America, where he managed the New Charleston Theatre in Charleston, South Carolina, in 1837.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays, Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Foscari at Covent Garden Theatre in 1828; Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. He was primarily a Covent Garden actor, playing secondary characters in tragedy. He also managed the Sadler's Wells theater and the Olympic Theatre in the early 1820s. In 1833, he opened the Victoria Theatre, formerly known as the Coburg, with William Abbott. He retired the following year.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed. Active 1810s to 1830s.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.
Dutch Golden Age landscape painter, the son of Salomon van Ruysdael, the cousin of Jacob van Ruisdael, and the teacher of Meindart Hobbema.

Actress who appeared in her first professional role as Claudia in Rienzi at at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Mitford intitially expressed concern over the casting of the inexperienced Miss Phillips, but later praised her for her emotionally-charged portrayal. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. The wife of actor Alfred Wigan, she later appeared as Mrs. Wigan.

Musician, born in Reading, who composed the music for Mitford's opera Sadak and Kalasrade; or the Waters of Oblivion in 1835. He studied at the Royal Academy of Musicin London and was a composer and singer as well as performer on the pianoforte and organ. In 1839, he was convicted of forgery and sentenced to life transportation to the Australian colonies. He performed and took pupils at Hobart Town, Tasmania, and was conditionally pardoned in 1850. He later moved to Sydney, where he continued to perform and to compose. In 1863, his career was curtailed when he was convicted of bigamy and sentenced to five years' hard labor. While imprisoned, he continued to compose and perform and he resumed teaching and composing upon his release, although never with his previous success. His best-known work was an oratorio, Crown of Thorns, or Despair, Penitence and Pardon (1863).
